message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including abdominal pain, diarrhea, difficulty sleeping, and hyperactive bowel sounds, suggest opioid withdrawal. The irritable behavior, cool and damp skin, and dilated pupils are also symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid, cannabis, and phencyclidine do not typically cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain, diarrhea, difficulty sleeping, and hyperactive bowel sounds suggest opioid withdrawal, which is caused by Heroin. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) withdrawal can cause similar symptoms, but the piloerection and hyperactive reflexes are not typical. Cannabis and phencyclidine (PCP) do not cause physical dependence, and withdrawal from these substances does not typically present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of opiate withdrawal, such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. The hyperactive bowel sounds and 3+ deep tendon reflexes are consistent with opiate withdrawal. The other options do not typically cause these symptoms.

The abdominal pain and hyperactive bowel sounds are classical symptoms of opioid withdrawal, along with chills, runny nose, and dilated pupils.

The irritable behavior and elevated heart rate are also common symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid, cannabis, and phencyclidine withdrawal do not typically present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and chills suggest heroin withdrawal. The irritable behavior, hyperactive bowel sounds, and increased reflexes also point to heroin withdrawal. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) withdrawal can cause hyperthermia, tachycardia, and hypertension. Cannabis and phencyclidine (PCP) do not typically cause physical withdrawal symptoms.

Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid can cause sedation, while Cannabis and Phencyclidine are not typically associated with the symptoms described.
